exercise.title: L'Hôpital's Rule to evaluate a limit

statement.p:
Let f and g be differentiable functions about which the following information is known: f(3) = g(3) = 0, f'(3) = g'(3) = 0, f''(3) = -2, and g''(3) = 1. Let a new function h be given by the rule h(x) = \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}. On the same set of axes, sketch possible graphs of f and g near x = 3, and use the provided information to determine the value of
\lim_{x \to 3} h(x) .
Provide explanation to support your conclusion.

solution.p:
See the figure below for possible graphs of f and g. To evaluate the limit, we can apply L'Hôpital's Rule twice. Since f(3) = g(3) = 0, we know by the rule that
\lim_{x \to 3} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} = \lim_{x \to 3} \frac{f'(x)}{g'(x)} . Since f'(3) = g'(3) = 0, the limit is still indeterminate, and we can apply the rule again to get
\lim_{x \to 3} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} = \lim_{x \to 3} \frac{f''(x)}{g''(x)} = \frac{f''(3)}{g''(3)} = \frac{-2}{1} . Hence, \lim_{x \to 3} h(x) = -2.

statement.p:
Find all vertical and horizontal asymptotes of the function
R(x) = \frac{3(x-a)(x-b)}{5(x-a)(x-c)} , where a, b, and c are distinct, arbitrary constants. In addition, state all values of x for which R is not continuous. Sketch a possible graph of R, clearly labeling the values of a, b, and c.

solution.p: Next, since b and c are distinct, we see that the numerator of R is zero (and the denominator is not) when x = b, and thus R(b) = 0. In addition, the denominator is zero (and the numerator is not) when x = c, and this results in there being a vertical asymptote at x = c.

Finally, we observe that x = a makes both the numerator and denominator zero. Since R(a) is thus not defined, the graph of R has either a hole or a vertical asymptote at x = a. To determine which, we evaluate the limit and see that
\lim_{x \to a} \frac{3(x-a)(x-b)}{5(x-a)(x-c)} = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{3(x-b)}{5(x-c)} = \frac{3(a-b)}{5(a-c)} . This tells us that R has a hole at the point (a, \frac{3(a-b)}{5(a-c)}). Moreover, R is not continuous at x = a and x = c.

statement.p:
Consider the function g(x) = x^{2x}, which is defined for all x \gt 0. Observe that \lim_{x \to 0^+} g(x) is indeterminate due to its form of 0^0. (Think about how we know that 0^k = 0 for all k \gt 0, while b^0 = 1 for all b \ne 0, but that neither rule can apply to 0^0.)
Let h(x) = \ln(g(x)). Explain why h(x) = 2x \ln(x).
Next, explain why it is equivalent to write h(x) = \frac{2\ln(x)}{\frac{1}{x}}.
Use L'Hôpital's Rule and your work in (b) to compute \lim_{x \to 0^+} h(x).
Based on the value of \lim_{x \to 0^+} h(x), determine \lim_{x \to 0^+} g(x).

li.p:
Since h(x) = \ln(g(x)) and we are given that g(x) = x^{2x}, it follows that
h(x) = \ln(x^{2x}) = 2x \cdot \ln(x) .

Since x = (x^{-1})^{-1} = \frac{1}{\frac{1}{x}}, we can also write
h(x) = \frac{2\ln(x)}{\frac{1}{x}} .

Since \ln(x) \to -\infty as x \to 0^+ and \frac{1}{x} \to +\infty as x \to 0^+, we see that
\lim_{x \to 0^+} h(x) = \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{2\ln(x)}{\frac{1}{x}}
is of an indeterminate form to which we can apply L'Hôpital's Rule. Doing so,
\lim_{x \to 0^+} h(x) = \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{2\ln(x)}{\frac{1}{x}} = \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\frac{2}{x}}{-\frac{1}{x^2}}
Simplifying algebraically,
\lim_{x \to 0^+} h(x) = \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{2}{x} \cdot \left(-\frac{x^2}{1}\right) = \lim_{x \to 0^+} (-2x)
Hence, it follows that \lim_{x \to 0^+} h(x) = 0.

Having shown that \lim_{x \to 0^+} h(x) = 0 and recalling that h(x) = \ln(g(x)), we know that as x \to 0^+, the natural log of g(x) tends to 0. Since \ln(1) = 0, it must be the case that g(x) is tending to 1, and thus
\lim_{x \to 0^+} g(x) = \lim_{x \to 0^+} x^{2x} = 1

statement.p:
Recall we say that function g dominates dominates function f provided that \lim_{x \to \infty} f(x) = \infty, \lim_{x \to \infty} g(x) = \infty, and \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} = 0.
Which function dominates the other: \ln(x) or \sqrt{x}?
Which function dominates the other: \ln(x) or \sqrt[n]{x}? (n can be any positive integer)
Explain why e^x will dominate any polynomial function.
Explain why x^n will dominate \ln(x) for any positive integer n.
Give any example of two nonlinear functions such that neither dominates the other.

li.p:
We note that both \ln(x) or \sqrt{x} increase without bound as x \to \infty, so we consider
\lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{\ln(x)}{\sqrt{x}} . By L'Hôpital's Rule and some simplifying algebra,
\lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{\ln(x)}{\sqrt{x}} = \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{\frac{1}{x}}{\frac{1}{2x^{1/2}}} = \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{2x^{1/2}}{x} = \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{2}{x^{1/2}} . Thus, it follows that
\lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{\ln(x)}{\sqrt{x}} = 0 , and hence \sqrt{x} dominates \ln(x).

Using a similar argument to our work in (a), we can show that \sqrt[n]{x} dominates \ln(x) for any positive integer n. In particular, by L'Hôpital's Rule and some simplifying algebra,
\lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{\ln(x)}{\sqrt[n]{x}} = \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{\frac{1}{x}}{\frac{1}{nx^{(n-1)/n}}} = \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{nx^{(n-1)/n}}{x} . Since \frac{x^{(n-1)/n}}{x} = x^{(n-1)/n - 1} = x^{(n-1-n)/n} = x^{-1/n}, it follows that
\lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{\ln(x)}{\sqrt[n]{x}} = \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{1}{x^{1/n}} = 0
we've shown that \sqrt[n]{x} dominates \ln(x) for any positive integer n.

Here we naturally consider the limit of the quotient of \ln(x) and x^n, where n \ge 1. Since both functions increase without bound, we can apply LHR. Doing so along with some simplifying algebra, we see
\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{\ln(x)}{x^n} = \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{x}}{nx^{n-1}} = \frac{1}{nx^n} = 0
and thus x^n indeed dominates.

Consider f(x) = 3x^2 + 1 and g(x) = -0.5x^2 + 5x - 2. Since these functions are polynomials of the same degree, we know
\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} = \frac{3}{-0.5} = -6 .
